elements.content: The metal–organic framework [Y­(tbpp)]·nDMF (1) was synthesized from yttrium­(III) nitrate and the tritopic linker tris­(4′-carboxy­[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)­phosphine (H3tbpp). The distance between the coordinating atoms of the carboxylate groups of the extended tridentate phosphine linker is more than 1.8 nm, resulting in an average pore dimension of 0.9 nm in the noninterpenetrated metal–organic framework. The material exhibits high thermal stability and permanent porosity after removal of guest molecules from the one-dimensional pore system. The desolvated compound adsorbs nitrogen, argon, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide. Favorable adsorption of CO2 over N2 is predicted using ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST). The isosteric enthalpies of adsorption of H2 and CO2 of −7 and −22 kJ mol–1, respectively, are representative for metal−organic frameworks with no accessible strong host–guest binding sites, despite the bifunctional nature of the organic ligand. The absence of strong specific adsorption sites was confirmed by in situ powder synchrotron X-ray diffraction of the reversible isobaric CO2 sorption process. Analysis of the diffraction data indicates that the CO2 molecules in the pores are disordered and nonlocalized. Despite this, it was possible to quantify the evolution of the occupation of the pores. CO2 is adsorbed at an approximately constant below 320 K from 10% loading to full capacity at 195 K.

The distance between the coordinating atoms of the carboxylate groups of the extended tridentate phosphine linker is more than 1.8 nm, resulting in an average pore dimension of 0.9 nm in the noninterpenetrated metal-organic framework. The material exhibits high thermal stability and permanent porosity after removal of guest molecules from the one-dimensional pore system. The desolvated compound adsorbs nitrogen, argon, hydrogen, and carbon dioxide. Favorable adsorption of CO2 over N2 is predicted using ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST). The isosteric enthalpies of adsorption of H2 and CO2 of -7 and -22 kJ mol-1, respectively, are representative for metal-organic frameworks with no accessible strong host-guest binding sites, despite the bifunctional nature of the organic ligand. The absence of strong specific adsorption sites was confirmed by in situ powder synchrotron X-ray diffraction of the reversible isobaric CO2 sorption process. Analysis of the diffraction data indicates that the CO2 molecules in the pores are disordered and nonlocalized. Despite this, it was possible to quantify the evolution of the occupation of the pores. CO2 is adsorbed at an approximately constant below 320 K from 10% loading to full capacity at 195 K.

elements.content: The three-dimensional, noninterpenetrated metal−organic framework [Y­(tbpp)]·nDMF was synthesized using yttrium­(III) and an extended tridentate phosphine linker. The permanently porous material readily adsorbs N2, Ar, H2, and CO2, and it preferentially adsorbs CO2 over N2. A detailed study of the CO2 adsorption process by in situ powder X-ray diffraction using synchrotron radiation indicates that there are no strong adsorption sites in the channels.
elements.clean_text: The three-dimensional, noninterpenetrated metal-organic framework [Y(tbpp)]⋅nDMF was synthesized using yttrium(III) and an extended tridentate phosphine linker. The permanently porous material readily adsorbs N2, Ar, H2, and CO2, and it preferentially adsorbs CO2 over N2. A detailed study of the CO2 adsorption process by in situ powder X-ray diffraction using synchrotron radiation indicates that there are no strong adsorption sites in the channels.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are coordination networks with solvent-filled pores built up from inorganic and organic building blocks. These porous materials show an intriguing breadth of properties within application areas such as catalysis, sorption, and separation. The heterogeneity of the pore surface plays a crucial role in the specific interaction between the host framework and substrate or adsorbate. An advantage of the crystalline nature of MOFs is that structural information about the interaction between host framework and guest molecule can be gained using diffraction methods. In situ diffraction experiments following the adsorption of gases in MOFs have been a powerful tool in elucidating site-specific adsorbate–adsorbent interactions between gas molecules and Lewis acidic or Lewis basic sites on the pore surface.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are coordination networks with solvent-filled pores built up from inorganic and organic building blocks. These porous materials show an intriguing breadth of properties within application areas such as catalysis, sorption, and separation. The heterogeneity of the pore surface plays a crucial role in the specific interaction between the host framework and substrate or adsorbate. An advantage of the crystalline nature of MOFs is that structural information about the interaction between host framework and guest molecule can be gained using diffraction methods. In situ diffraction experiments following the adsorption of gases in MOFs have been a powerful tool in elucidating site-specific adsorbate-adsorbent interactions between gas molecules and Lewis acidic or Lewis basic sites on the pore surface.

elements.content: Several organic bridging linkers derived from triphenylphosphine have been used to prepare porous coordination polymers in which metal complexes were grafted to phosphine sites, in attempts to establish the viability of using the Lewis basic P­(III) atom of the phosphine group to immobilize catalytically active systems in the MOF. It would also be interesting to study the effect of the presence of the phosphine group on the selective adsorption of environmentally relevant gases such as CO2. However, the adsorption properties of these materials were usually evaluated using only nitrogen physisorption. There are only a few adsorption studies relevant to gas storage and separation in these MOFs. Humphrey et al. used tris­(4-carboxyphenyl)­phosphine (H3tpp) to prepare the porous calcium–organic framework PCM-10. Its structure contains one-dimensional pores with P­(III) sites exposed on the internal surface. PCM-10 adsorbed CO2 at 195 K and H2 at 77 K, while the adsorption of N2 and O2 was negligible. Postsynthetic modification of the P­(III) sites with an Au­(I) complex resulted in selective adsorption of 1-hexene over n-hexane at 303 K and an uptake of 4.72 wt % of H2 at 77 K. We recently used the H3tpp linker to synthesize the three MOFs [Zn3(tpp)2(DMF)2]·nDMF, [Zn3(tpp)2(4,4′-bpy)2]·nDMF, and [Zn3(tpp)2(3,3′-bpy)]·nDMF, all of which adsorbed CO2 at 195 K. A large gate effect was observed for [Zn3(tpp)2(3,3′-bpy)].

It would also be interesting to study the effect of the presence of the phosphine group on the selective adsorption of environmentally relevant gases such as CO2. However, the adsorption properties of these materials were usually evaluated using only nitrogen physisorption. There are only a few adsorption studies relevant to gas storage and separation in these MOFs. Humphrey et al. used tris(4-carboxyphenyl)phosphine (H3tpp) to prepare the porous calcium-organic framework PCM-10. Its structure contains one-dimensional pores with P(III) sites exposed on the internal surface. PCM-10 adsorbed CO2 at 195 K and H2 at 77 K, while the adsorption of N2 and O2 was negligible. Postsynthetic modification of the P(III) sites with an Au(I) complex resulted in selective adsorption of 1-hexene over n-hexane at 303 K and an uptake of 4.72 wt % of H2 at 77 K. We recently used the H3tpp linker to synthesize the three MOFs [Zn3(tpp)2(DMF)2]⋅nDMF, [Zn3(tpp)2(4,4'-bpy)2]⋅nDMF, and [Zn3(tpp)2(3,3'-bpy)]⋅nDMF, all of which adsorbed CO2 at 195 K. A large gate effect was observed for [Zn3(tpp)2(3,3'-bpy)].

elements.content: The use of extended linkers is a promising approach to obtain compounds with larger pores and a larger adsorption capacity. Here, we present the metal–organic framework [Y­(tbpp)]·nDMF (1) formed by reaction of the H3tbpp linker (H3tbpp = tris­(4′-carboxy­[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)­phosphine) and yttrium­(III) nitrate (). The noninterpenetrated framework 1 contains infinite chains of condensed yttrium coordination polyhedra and solvent-filled channels. The guest solvent molecules can be easily removed from the pores of the rigid framework, and the permanently porous compound readily adsorbs N2, H2, Ar, and CO2. We evaluated the potential for CO2/N2 separation using ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST). The high crystallinity of the desolvated material indicates that it should be possible to gain in-depth information about the CO2 sorption process in 1, which we investigated by in situ powder X-ray diffraction using synchrotron radiation.

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis of Compound 1

elements.content: All chemicals, reagents, and solvents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received without further purification. In order to prevent oxidation of the P­(III) in H3tbpp to P­(V), the synthesis was performed under an inert atmosphere. Manipulations under an inert atmosphere were performed using Schlenk techniques or in a glovebox (MBRAUN). Dimethylformamide (DMF) was deaerated using the freeze–pump–thaw procedure.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All chemicals, reagents, and solvents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received without further purification. In order to prevent oxidation of the P(III) in H3tbpp to P(V), the synthesis was performed under an inert atmosphere. Manipulations under an inert atmosphere were performed using Schlenk techniques or in a glovebox (MBRAUN). Dimethylformamide (DMF) was deaerated using the freeze-pump-thaw procedure.

elements.content: Tris­(4′-carboxy­[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)­phosphine (H3tbpp) was synthesized using an adapted procedure for the preparation of tris­(4-carboxyphenyl)­phosphine. A detailed description of the synthetic procedure is provided in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Organic Linker

Tris(4'-carboxy[1,1'-biphenyl]-4-yl)phosphine (H3tbpp) was synthesized using an adapted procedure for the preparation of tris(4-carboxyphenyl)phosphine. A detailed description of the synthetic procedure is provided in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Yttrium­(III) nitrate hexahydrate (191 mg, 0.5 mmol) and H3tbpp (311 mg, 0.5 mmol) were placed into a glass culture tube with a screw cap (Schott, ∼6 mL). The open tube was placed in a larger Schlenk flask. The atmosphere in the flask was exchanged to Ar, and deaerated DMF (1 mL) was added to the mixture of solids in the tube under Ar flow. The tube was sealed with the cap under Ar flow and taken out of the larger Schlenk flask. The reaction mixture was sonicated for 1 h. The tube was then placed in an oven preheated to 383 K. The tube was taken out after 5 days and cooled to room temperature. The solid product was filtered and washed with DMF. Yield: 355 mg (83% calculated on linker basis for [Y­(tbpp)]·2DMF). Anal. Calcd for C39H24O6PY·2.2C3H7NO·0.35H2O: C, 62.55; H, 4.62; N, 3.52. Found: C, 62.54; H, 4.59; N, 3.54.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Y(tbpp)]⋅nDMF (1)

Yttrium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (191 mg, 0.5 mmol) and H3tbpp (311 mg, 0.5 mmol) were placed into a glass culture tube with a screw cap (Schott, ~6 mL). The open tube was placed in a larger Schlenk flask. The atmosphere in the flask was exchanged to Ar, and deaerated DMF (1 mL) was added to the mixture of solids in the tube under Ar flow. The tube was sealed with the cap under Ar flow and taken out of the larger Schlenk flask. The reaction mixture was sonicated for 1 h. The tube was then placed in an oven preheated to 383 K. The tube was taken out after 5 days and cooled to room temperature. The solid product was filtered and washed with DMF. Yield: 355 mg (83% calculated on linker basis for [Y(tbpp)]⋅2DMF). Anal. Calcd for C39H24O6PY⋅2.2C3H7NO⋅0.35H2O: C, 62.55; H, 4.62; N, 3.52. Found: C, 62.54; H, 4.59; N, 3.54.

elements.content: A suitable crystal was mounted in a minimum amount of oil on a nylon loop. Intensity data for as-synthesized 1 was collected at beamline BM01A of the Swiss-Norwegian Beamlines (SNBL) at the ESRF using a custom-made one-axis diffractometer equipped with a Pilatus 2M detector and an Oxford Cryostream 700 system. Data processing was performed using the CrysAlisPro software. Structure solution was performed using SHELXT-2014/5, and refinement was performed using SHELXL-2014/3. The structure factor contributions from spatially disordered solvent molecules inside the pores were taken into account using SQUEEZE.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

A suitable crystal was mounted in a minimum amount of oil on a nylon loop. Intensity data for as-synthesized 1 was collected at beamline BM01A of the Swiss-Norwegian Beamlines (SNBL) at the ESRF using a custom-made one-axis diffractometer equipped with a Pilatus 2M detector and an Oxford Cryostream 700 system. Data processing was performed using the CrysAlisPro software. Structure solution was performed using SHELXT-2014/5, and refinement was performed using SHELXL-2014/3. The structure factor contributions from spatially disordered solvent molecules inside the pores were taken into account using SQUEEZE.

elements.content: As-synthesized 1 was pretreated under a dynamic vacuum at 473 K overnight in order to remove guest solvent molecules. The desolvated sample was transferred into a glovebox and filled into a 0.5 mm glass capillary. Quartz-glass wool was placed on top of the sample in the capillary in order to reduce the risk of the sample moving within the capillary as the pressure changed during the adsorption experiment. The capillary was flame-sealed for transportation.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction and Isobaric CO2 Sorption Experiment

As-synthesized 1 was pretreated under a dynamic vacuum at 473 K overnight in order to remove guest solvent molecules. The desolvated sample was transferred into a glovebox and filled into a 0.5 mm glass capillary. Quartz-glass wool was placed on top of the sample in the capillary in order to reduce the risk of the sample moving within the capillary as the pressure changed during the adsorption experiment. The capillary was flame-sealed for transportation.

elements.content: Variable-temperature in situ powder X-ray diffraction under static CO2 pressure was performed at beamline BM01A of the Swiss-Norwegian Beamlines (SNBL) at the ESRF. A custom sample holder was used for the experiment. A glass capillary with the sample and wool inside was glued to the sample holder. The sample holder was connected to a gas dosing system, which allowed exposure of the sample to vacuum or to CO2. An Oxford Cryostream 700 system was used to heat and cool the sample. The sample was heated at 453 K under a dynamic vacuum for 20 min in order to ensure the absence of guest molecules. Then, CO2 was dosed at a pressure of 1 bar and the temperature was decreased from 453 to 195 K with a ramp of 2 K min–1. The sample was kept for 15 min at 195 K in order to allow the system to reach equilibrium, after which the sample was heated to 298 K with a ramp of 2 K min–1.
elements.clean_text: Variable-temperature in situ powder X-ray diffraction under static CO2 pressure was performed at beamline BM01A of the Swiss-Norwegian Beamlines (SNBL) at the ESRF. A custom sample holder was used for the experiment. A glass capillary with the sample and wool inside was glued to the sample holder. The sample holder was connected to a gas dosing system, which allowed exposure of the sample to vacuum or to CO2. An Oxford Cryostream 700 system was used to heat and cool the sample. The sample was heated at 453 K under a dynamic vacuum for 20 min in order to ensure the absence of guest molecules. Then, CO2 was dosed at a pressure of 1 bar and the temperature was decreased from 453 to 195 K with a ramp of 2 K min-1. The sample was kept for 15 min at 195 K in order to allow the system to reach equilibrium, after which the sample was heated to 298 K with a ramp of 2 K min-1.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction intensity data were collected using a custom-made diffractometer equipped with a Pilatus 2M detector. 2D frames were integrated azimuthal using the Bubble tool. Pawley profile fits of the powder diffraction patterns were performed using TOPAS 4.2. The structure of desolvated 1 was determined by Rietveld refinement using TOPAS 6 Academic. The Fourier electron density difference maps were calculated from powder X-ray diffraction patterns using a procedure described by Smeets et al.
elements.clean_text: Powder X-ray diffraction intensity data were collected using a custom-made diffractometer equipped with a Pilatus 2M detector. 2D frames were integrated azimuthal using the Bubble tool. Pawley profile fits of the powder diffraction patterns were performed using TOPAS 4.2. The structure of desolvated 1 was determined by Rietveld refinement using TOPAS 6 Academic. The Fourier electron density difference maps were calculated from powder X-ray diffraction patterns using a procedure described by Smeets et al.

Thermal Analysis

A Netzsch STA 449 F1 Jupiter instrument was used for simultaneous thermogravimetry and differential scanning calorimetry. Measurements were performed using a flow of pure Ar or O2/Ar (20/80 mixture) and a heating rate of 2 K min-1.

elements.content: Gas adsorption measurements were carried out on a BELSORP-max instrument. The gases used were of 99.9995%, or higher, purity and were purchased from Yara Praxair. As-synthesized 1 was pretreated by heating under a dynamic vacuum at 473 K overnight. The sample was transferred into the glovebox, where sample cells were filled and transferred to the instrument under an inert atmosphere using quick seals. Prior to the sorption experiment, the sample cells were again heated overnight under a dynamic vacuum at 473 K. Cross-sectional areas of 0.162, 0.142, and 0.195 nm2 were used for N2, Ar, and CO2, respectively, in the calculation of the specific surface area. Ideal solution adsorbed theory (IAST) calculations were performed using the open-source Python package pyIAST.

Volumetric Gas Adsorption

Gas adsorption measurements were carried out on a BELSORP-max instrument. The gases used were of 99.9995%, or higher, purity and were purchased from Yara Praxair. As-synthesized 1 was pretreated by heating under a dynamic vacuum at 473 K overnight. The sample was transferred into the glovebox, where sample cells were filled and transferred to the instrument under an inert atmosphere using quick seals. Prior to the sorption experiment, the sample cells were again heated overnight under a dynamic vacuum at 473 K. Cross-sectional areas of 0.162, 0.142, and 0.195 nm2 were used for N2, Ar, and CO2, respectively, in the calculation of the specific surface area. Ideal solution adsorbed theory (IAST) calculations were performed using the open-source Python package pyIAST.

elements.content: The presence of Lewis basic sites in the structure of MOFs frequently facilitates the selective adsorption of gas molecules such as CO2. Examples of CO2 adsorption in metal–organic frameworks with uncoordinated Lewis basic P­(III) sites are so far limited to frameworks based on tris­(4-carboxyphenyl)­phosphine (H3tpp). It is a natural progression to employ an extended derivative of H3tpp in the preparation of the framework compound in the expectation that it would lead to larger pore sizes and adsorption capacities. Tris­(4′-carboxy­[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)­phosphine (H3tbpp) is a rigid molecule with a distance of ∼18–19 Å between carboxylic acid groups, which implies the potential to obtain networks with large pore sizes. In cases where the organic linker is not commercially available, linker synthesis frequently becomes the reaction step determining progress in the discovery of new MOFs. Lin et al. recently synthesized the H3tbpp linker using a C–C cross-coupling reaction. Herein, we used an alternative synthetic route that requires only two steps starting from commercially available reactants and avoids the use of the costly palladium-based coupling agent.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The presence of Lewis basic sites in the structure of MOFs frequently facilitates the selective adsorption of gas molecules such as CO2. Examples of CO2 adsorption in metal-organic frameworks with uncoordinated Lewis basic P(III) sites are so far limited to frameworks based on tris(4-carboxyphenyl)phosphine (H3tpp). It is a natural progression to employ an extended derivative of H3tpp in the preparation of the framework compound in the expectation that it would lead to larger pore sizes and adsorption capacities. Tris(4'-carboxy[1,1'-biphenyl]-4-yl)phosphine (H3tbpp) is a rigid molecule with a distance of ~18-19 Å between carboxylic acid groups, which implies the potential to obtain networks with large pore sizes. In cases where the organic linker is not commercially available, linker synthesis frequently becomes the reaction step determining progress in the discovery of new MOFs. Lin et al. recently synthesized the H3tbpp linker using a C-C cross-coupling reaction. Herein, we used an alternative synthetic route that requires only two steps starting from commercially available reactants and avoids the use of the costly palladium-based coupling agent.

elements.content: We selected yttrium­(III) as counterion for synthesis of the MOF in expectation that the hard Lewis acid Y3+ will be exclusively coordinated by the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of the tbpp3– linker and not by the soft Lewis basic phosphorus atom. This synthetic strategy avoids formation of networks with metal–P coordination bonds, which have been obtained with other metal cations. Rather, it leads to formation of a framework structure with uncoordinated P atoms.
elements.clean_text: We selected yttrium(III) as counterion for synthesis of the MOF in expectation that the hard Lewis acid Y3+ will be exclusively coordinated by the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of the tbpp3- linker and not by the soft Lewis basic phosphorus atom. This synthetic strategy avoids formation of networks with metal-P coordination bonds, which have been obtained with other metal cations. Rather, it leads to formation of a framework structure with uncoordinated P atoms.

elements.content: Another challenge for the synthesis of MOFs with the H3tbpp linker is the ease of oxidation of P­(III) to P­(V)O at the elevated temperatures at which the solvothermal reaction is carried out. While the oxide derivative of the H3tbpp linker does form coordination polymers, the P­(V)O group is usually coordinated to oxophilic metal atoms and participates in formation of the framework. In order to avoid oxidation to the phosphine oxide and synthesize structures with the P­(III) moiety, reactions including the H3tbpp ligand have to be performed under an inert atmosphere with deaerated solvents, which significantly increases the effort required for the materials discovery process.

While the oxide derivative of the H3tbpp linker does form coordination polymers, the P(V)O group is usually coordinated to oxophilic metal atoms and participates in formation of the framework. In order to avoid oxidation to the phosphine oxide and synthesize structures with the P(III) moiety, reactions including the H3tbpp ligand have to be performed under an inert atmosphere with deaerated solvents, which significantly increases the effort required for the materials discovery process.

elements.content: Colorless single crystals of 1 were obtained by reaction of Y­(NO3)3·6H2O with H3tbpp in DMF for 5 days at 383 K under inert conditions. The trivalent metal cation and the linker anion bearing three carboxylate groups form a charge-neutral framework with 1:1 composition. 1 crystallizes in the noncentrosymmetric monoclinic space group Cc (). Each Y atom is coordinated by nine oxygen atoms belonging to six different carboxylate groups. The inorganic secondary building unit (SBU) consists of adjacent Y atoms that are connected through μ-η1:η2-coordinated carboxylate groups into an infinite chain of condensed Y coordination polyhedra parallel to the c axis (a). The inorganic SBUs are connected by tbpp3– linkers into a three-dimensional noninterpenetrated coordination network. The structure has pores in the shape of rhombic channels along the c axis, with diagonals of approximately 7 and 10 Å (b). The pores are filled with disordered solvent molecules in the as-synthesized compound. The solvent-accessible volume amounts to 1409 Å3 or 34% of the unit cell volume (calculated using PLATON), which is sufficient space to accommodate the two DMF solvent molecules per formula unit indicated by elemental and thermal analysis.

elements.content: As expected, the P atom of the H3tbpp linker is not coordinated to the yttrium atom in the structure of 1, as has also been the case for other coordination networks based on tridentate phosphine linkers. Unfortunately, the noncoordinated P atom in 1 is not accessible from the pore volume because it is pointing toward an adjacent molecule with which it forms a double wall between channels. This fact restricts the application of 1 in postmodification and as an anchor for catalytically active species.

elements.content: The H3tbpp linker is isostructural with other tritopic linkers that were used in syntheses of coordination networks: e.g., linkers containing N, B, or SiOH instead of P as the central atom. The use of some of these tritopic linkers has led to the formation of structures similar to 1, in which three-dimensional frameworks are built from various infinite chains of condensed coordination polyhedra interconnected by the linker around one-dimensional pores parallel to the direction of the chains. The compound [Ce­(L)]·1.5H2O·0.5EtOH·DMF (H3L = tris­(4′-carboxy­[1,1′-biphenyl]-4-yl)­amine) (FIR-8) actually crystallizes with a framework isostructural with 1. It is based on a nitrogen-containing linker and trivalent cerium cation and exhibits second-harmonic generation.

It is based on a nitrogen-containing linker and trivalent cerium cation and exhibits second-harmonic generation.

elements.content: Thermal analysis of as-synthesized 1 shows a decrease in weight of 16% at about 440 K, corresponding to the loss of two DMF molecules per formula unit (). Under an Ar atmosphere, the loss of the solvent is followed by a pronounced plateau in the temperature range 500–770 K, indicating that 1 remains stable after desolvation at elevated temperatures under an inert atmosphere. In an oxidizing environment (O2/Ar atmosphere) the weight percent signal does not significantly drop until ∼700 K. In fact, a weight increase of ∼2% is observed with a maximum at about 650 K. This weight increase corresponds to the addition of one O atom per tbpp3– anion and is in all likelihood due to the oxidation of P­(III) to P­(V)O.

elements.content: The solvent molecules can be removed from the pores of as-synthesized 1 by treating the sample at 473 K under a dynamic vacuum overnight. The desolvated material adsorbs N2, H2, Ar, and CO2 (). The Langmuir and BET specific surface areas values are 915 and 781 m2 g–1 for N2, 814 and 663 m2 g–1 for Ar, and 903 and 747 m2 g–1 for CO2, respectively. The observed total pore volume of 0.32 cm3 g–1 (at p/p 0 = 0.5 for N2 adsorption) corresponds well to the pore volume of 0.29 cm3 g–1 calculated for the single-crystal structure using PLATON. A narrow pore diameter distribution with a maximum at 9 Å was found from the Ar adsorption isotherm at 87 K and NLDFT calculations with a cylindrical pore model (Figure S14 in the Supporting Information), corresponding well with the rhombus profile of the channel with diagonals of about 10 and 7 Å as determined from the single-crystal structure of as-synthesized 1.

elements.content: Desolvated 1 remains highly crystalline (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information). Its crystal structure was determined by Rietveld refinement of powder X-ray diffraction data using synchrotron radiation collected at 453 K under dynamic vacuum (a). The structure of desolvated 1 differs from the single-crystal structure of as-synthesized 1 only in minor conformational changes (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information), which confirms that 1 is a rigid (second-generation) permanently porous MOF. The absence of significant electron density in the pores in the Fourier difference map confirms the successful removal of solvent guest molecules (a).

elements.content: We subsequently exposed this desolvated sample to CO2 under isobaric conditions (p = 1 bar) and collected in situ powder X-ray diffraction data while cooling and heating the sample in an attempt to follow the adsorption and desorption process and gain structural information about dynamic processes occurring in 1. Upon exposure to CO2 and continuous decrease of the temperature from 453 to 195 K, increasing amounts of CO2 are adsorbed in 1, which is reflected by continuous changes in relative intensities of the reflections in the powder X-ray diffraction patterns (b). There is no significant change in the lattice parameters during adsorption, which corroborates the rigidity of the framework during the adsorption process. The relative change is 0.4% for a, 0.5% for b, and 0.7% for c in the temperature range 453–195 K (). The powder pattern at 195 K, at which the pores are fully filled with CO2, exhibits a distribution of relative intensities similar to those for as-synthesized 1 with solvent molecules in the pores (a). The intensities of the [020] and [200] reflections relative to the [110] reflection are the most affected by the pore content of the framework, whether it is solvent or adsorbed CO2 molecules (b,c).

elements.content: Regrettably, our attempts to localize the CO2 molecules in the pores of the fully loaded structure at 195 K did not succeed, despite the excellent quality of the diffraction data and clear differences in the relative intensity distributions of the desolvated and CO2-loaded compounds. The most likely explanation for the failure to find definite locations for the CO2 molecules is that the individual CO2 molecules are disordered instead of being on well-defined positions in the pore. This interpretation is corroborated by the Fourier electron density difference maps obtained for two exemplary temperatures, representing different CO2 occupancies (b,c). There is significant electron density located in the pores at both 270 and 195 K, confirming that 1 adsorbed increasing amounts of CO2 as the temperature was decreased under isobaric pressure. The electron cloud is relatively diffuse in the pores at 270 K (b). At 195 K (c), at which the amount of adsorbed CO2 is maximal, the electron density is distributed inside the pore channel following the shape of the Connolly surface more closely, thus filling the pores more completely in comparison to the lower density at the higher temperature. In neither map are there isolated maxima of electron density that indicate the presence of well-localized individual CO2 molecules.

elements.content: Even though the determination of well-defined host–guest structures was not possible, we were able to obtain a more detailed picture of the sorption process by quantification of the number of CO2 molecules that are adsorbed in the pores at variable temperature. The electron density in the pores due to the adsorbed disordered CO2 can be accounted for using the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON (), which was performed on hkl intensity sets obtained from Rietveld refinements using the fixed structural model of desolvated 1. The calculated CO2 uptake continuously changes over time, reflecting the smooth change in intensities in the powder X-ray diffraction patterns (b,c). Upon cooling from 453 to 320 K, the uptake changes from 3% to 10%. Below ∼320 K, it increases more quickly and reaches 100% at 195 K with an approximately constant slope. The CO2 uptake decreases again with a similar slope upon heating, showing the easy reversibility of the adsorption and desorption processes, neither of which appears to be kinetically hindered. The numbers of CO2 molecules adsorbed at 278, 288, and 298 K normalized to the maximum uptake at 195 K correspond perfectly for measurements under isobaric and isothermal conditions (Figure S12 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Volumetric gas adsorption experiments (Figure S13 in the Supporting Information) were used to quantify the strength of the interaction between framework and adsorptive. The isosteric enthalpy of adsorption of CO2 in the temperature range 278–298 K is about −22 kJ mol–1 (a), which is in the range usually found for MOFs without preferred strong adsorption sites such as open-metal sites or available Lewis basic sites. Hydrogen adsorption at 77 and 87 K achieved higher coverage of the internal surface in comparison to CO2 adsorption close to room temperature. The isosteric enthalpy of adsorption of hydrogen does not change significantly as the H2 uptake increases to three molecules per formula unit (a), indicating that different adsorption sites are energetically similar. At approximately −7 kJ mol–1, it is again typical for MOFs without strong adsorption sites.

elements.content: The rigidity of the framework 1 during the adsorption process allowed us to apply ideal solution adsorbed theory (IAST) calculations to predict mixed-gas adsorption isotherms (b) from pure-gas isotherms of CO2 and N2 (Figure S15 in the Supporting Information). The IAST calculations were performed for a binary mixture of 15% CO2 and 85% N2, simulating the content of CO2 in flue gas. The predicted adsorption selectivity of CO2 over N2 is about 11 at 278 K, what is lower than CO2/N2 selectivity values predicted with IAST for MOFs with strong adsorption sites. Still, the selectivity value demonstrates that, even in the absence of open metal sites or accessible Lewis basic sites in the structure, desolvated 1 favors the adsorption of CO2 over N2.

elements.content: We have demonstrated that the extended tridentate phosphine linker can be used to prepare MOFs with permanent porosity, high thermal stability, and large pore sizes. The rigid noninterpenetrated porous metal–organic framework 1 is permanently porous and remains crystalline after solvent removal with rhombus-shaped channels with an average pore size of ∼9 Å. It adsorbs N2, Ar, H2, and CO2. The CO2 sorption process was also monitored using variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction at static pressure, from which the amount of adsorbed CO2 was estimated. IAST calculations predict that 1 adsorbs CO2 selectively over N2.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have demonstrated that the extended tridentate phosphine linker can be used to prepare MOFs with permanent porosity, high thermal stability, and large pore sizes. The rigid noninterpenetrated porous metal-organic framework 1 is permanently porous and remains crystalline after solvent removal with rhombus-shaped channels with an average pore size of ~9 Å. It adsorbs N2, Ar, H2, and CO2. The CO2 sorption process was also monitored using variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction at static pressure, from which the amount of adsorbed CO2 was estimated. IAST calculations predict that 1 adsorbs CO2 selectively over N2.

cln_elements.content: Yttrium­(III) nitrate hexahydrate (191 mg, 0.5 mmol) and H3tbpp (311 mg, 0.5 mmol) were placed into a glass culture tube with a screw cap (Schott, ∼6 mL). The open tube was placed in a larger Schlenk flask. The atmosphere in the flask was exchanged to Ar, and deaerated DMF (1 mL) was added to the mixture of solids in the tube under Ar flow. The tube was sealed with the cap under Ar flow and taken out of the larger Schlenk flask. The reaction mixture was sonicated for 1 h. The tube was then placed in an oven preheated to 383 K. The tube was taken out after 5 days and cooled to room temperature. The solid product was filtered and washed with DMF. Yield: 355 mg (83% calculated on linker basis for [Y­(tbpp)]·2DMF). Anal. Calcd for C39H24O6PY·2.2C3H7NO·0.35H2O: C, 62.55; H, 4.62; N, 3.52. Found: C, 62.54; H, 4.59; N, 3.54.

Synthesis of [Y(tbpp)]⋅nDMF (1)

Yttrium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (191 mg, 0.5 mmol) and H3tbpp (311 mg, 0.5 mmol) were placed into a glass culture tube with a screw cap (Schott, ~6 mL). The open tube was placed in a larger Schlenk flask. The atmosphere in the flask was exchanged to Ar, and deaerated DMF (1 mL) was added to the mixture of solids in the tube under Ar flow. The tube was sealed with the cap under Ar flow and taken out of the larger Schlenk flask. The reaction mixture was sonicated for 1 h. The tube was then placed in an oven preheated to 383 K. The tube was taken out after 5 days and cooled to room temperature. The solid product was filtered and washed with DMF. Yield: 355 mg (83% calculated on linker basis for [Y(tbpp)]⋅2DMF). Anal. Calcd for C39H24O6PY⋅2.2C3H7NO⋅0.35H2O: C, 62.55; H, 4.62; N, 3.52. Found: C, 62.54; H, 4.59; N, 3.54.

cln_elements.content:
Thermal analysis of as-synthesized 1 shows a decrease in weight of 16% at about 440 K, corresponding to the loss of two DMF molecules per formula unit (). Under an Ar atmosphere, the loss of the solvent is followed by a pronounced plateau in the temperature range 500–770 K, indicating that 1 remains stable after desolvation at elevated temperatures under an inert atmosphere. In an oxidizing environment (O2/Ar atmosphere) the weight percent signal does not significantly drop until ∼700 K. In fact, a weight increase of ∼2% is observed with a maximum at about 650 K. This weight increase corresponds to the addition of one O atom per tbpp3– anion and is in all likelihood due to the oxidation of P­(III) to P­(V)O.

The solvent molecules can be removed from the pores of as-synthesized 1 by treating the sample at 473 K under a dynamic vacuum overnight. The desolvated material adsorbs N2, H2, Ar, and CO2 (). The Langmuir and BET specific surface areas values are 915 and 781 m2 g–1 for N2, 814 and 663 m2 g–1 for Ar, and 903 and 747 m2 g–1 for CO2, respectively. The observed total pore volume of 0.32 cm3 g–1 (at p/p 0 = 0.5 for N2 adsorption) corresponds well to the pore volume of 0.29 cm3 g–1 calculated for the single-crystal structure using PLATON. A narrow pore diameter distribution with a maximum at 9 Å was found from the Ar adsorption isotherm at 87 K and NLDFT calculations with a cylindrical pore model (Figure S14 in the Supporting Information), corresponding well with the rhombus profile of the channel with diagonals of about 10 and 7 Å as determined from the single-crystal structure of as-synthesized 1.
